channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Underground Ordeal Ends for German Researcher Injured in Deep Alpine Cave
item.description: Johann Westhauser was struck on the head by a rock on June 8 while exploring the depths of an alpine cavern known as the Riesending, or Big Thing.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Mr. Westhauser was evacuated on Thursday by helicopter.

item.title: Turkish Court Orders Release of Officers Convicted of Plotting Coup
item.description: The officers were among 330 convicted in the “Sledgehammer” case, so called because of the code name of an alleged plot to destabilize the government.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Analysts Say China May Try to Use Manmade Islands to Bolster Bid for Economic Development
item.description: Analysts say China could try to assert that new islands in disputed waters entitle the country to exclusive economic zones just off the coastlines.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A Philippine surveillance photo shows an island that China has created on a reef among the disputed Spratly Islands in the South China Sea.

item.title: Help From the Left Keeps a Right-Wing President in Power in Colombia
item.description: By declaring a vote for Juan Manuel Santos as a vote in favor of peace negotiations with rebel groups, Clara López made the country’s left politically relevant again.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Clara López, left, has been credited with playing a decisive role in the re-election of President Juan Manuel Santos, right.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Brother of Aide to Former Chinese Leader Comes Under Investigation
item.description: Ling Zhengce, the deputy head of a government advisory body in the coal-rich northern province of Shanxi, is the target of an investigation by the Communist Party for “suspected grave violations of regulations and law,” which in past cases has referred to corruption.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE, CHRIS BUCKLEY and JONATHAN ANSFIELD
item.media:description: Ling Jihua, a top aide to Hu Jintao, the former president of China.

item.title: Lens Blog: Pulling Back the Veil, or Keeping It On
item.description: A Yemeni photographer worked both sides of the camera as she and her daughter – and a doll – posed for a visual mediation on the increasing covering of women.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: In Spain, Soccer Team’s Ouster Casts Pall Over New King’s Arrival
item.description: Nobody in Spain suspected that the arrival of a new king after the old king’s abdication would coincide with the elimination of Spain from the World Cup.
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Iraqi Factions Jockey to Oust Maliki, Citing U.S. Support
item.description: Iraqi leaders, alarmed over the Sunni insurgency, are actively seeking to replace Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki with someone supported by all Iraqi sects.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Sunni militants on Thursday near the Baiji oil refinery in northern Iraq.

item.title: Text of Obama’s Remarks on Iraq
item.description: The following is the complete transcript of President Obama’s statements on Thursday about the conflict in Iraq.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: United States to Send Military Advisers to Iraq
item.description: Ruling out combat forces, President Obama said the United States will send up to 300 advisers to help Iraq repel Sunni militants who have captured several cities.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama speaking about Iraq on Thursday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 19
item.description: India receives annual rainfall from June to September.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: China Plans to Send Second Oil Rig to Waters Near Vietnam
item.description: Even as the two countries are in dispute over a Chinese oil rig in the South China Sea, Beijing is pressing ahead with new plans to assert its rights there.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Protesters demonstrating against China in Hanoi on Thursday. The dispatch of a second oil rig in the South China Sea began on Wednesday.

item.title: Open Source: Israelis Start #BringBackOurBoys Campaign
item.description: Israelis trained to promote their country’s image online started a campaign last week, using a hashtag inspired by Nigerian activists, after three teenagers disappeared on their way home from religious schools in the occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot of a tweet deleted on Tuesday night from the Twitter account of an Israeli expert in public diplomacy.

item.title: Open Source: After 10 Months in Jail, Freed Egyptian Journalist Says, ‘I Have Won’
item.description: By the time he was finally set free late Tuesday, Abdullah Elshamy, 25, had been held without charge for 10 months.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Open Source: Twitter Restores Access to ‘Blasphemous’ Tweets in Pakistan
item.description: Twitter reversed a decision it made last month to block content in Pakistan deemed “blasphemous” or “unethical” by a government regulator.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Iraqi Political Leaders Maneuvering to Replace Maliki
item.description: American and Iraqi officials said the political leaders, alarmed over the Sunni insurgency, were seeking a replacement supported by all Iraqi sects.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a Shiite, has marginalized other Iraqi groups and has been widely blamed for the ballooning Sunni insurgency.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Opponents of Hong Kong’s Occupy Central Envision Chaos
item.description: A group opposed to the Occupy Central movement has released a video that depicts the possibility of civil disobedience as a knife stabbing the heart of Hong Kong, saying such protests would bring the city to a halt.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY and ALAN WONG

item.title: With World Cup in Headlines, a Debate Continues on What to Call the Game
item.description: A new academic paper suggests that the word soccer began in Britain and was used there happily until at least the 1970s, even as a spirited debate over the sport’s name endures.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:description: A New York Times article from Oct. 22, 1905, used the term “Socker” in the headline.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Uses ‘House of Cards’ as Illustration of West’s Corruption
item.description: The Communist Party’s top graft investigation group has published an article using the series “House of Cards” as evidence of the extent of influence-peddling in the West and argue that China is fundamentally different.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:credit: Nathaniel E. Bell/Netflix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kevin Spacey as Frank Underwood in "House of Cards," which is being cited in China as a faithful portrayal of the depths of official corruption in Western developed countries.

item.title: Clashes Reported in Ukraine After Cease-Fire Proposal
item.description: Residents of Krasny Liman, a railroad hub, said they had heard heavy shelling outside the town near a checkpoint previously held by rebels.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Polish Premier Says He May Call Early Elections
item.description: A scandal touched off by secretly recorded conversations of senior members of the government has eroded confidence, Prime Minister Donald Tusk said.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: “If the crisis of confidence becomes too deep, perhaps the only way out will be early elections,” said Prime Minister Donald Tusk.

item.title: Iraqi Officials Claim Control of Major Refinery in Baiji
item.description: A military spokesman said militants had been driven from the oil refinery in Baiji, but witnesses said the rebels’ black banners were still flying from some buildings.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and SUADAD AL-SALHY
item.media:description: The oil refinery in Baiji, in 2009. It could give militants a major source of revenue.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Ethiopia’s Condom Dilemma
item.description: Giveaway programs sponsored by aid donors have suppressed H.I.V. infection rates but also stifled market solutions.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES JEFFREY

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Does Germany Need a New Flag?
item.description: Our black, yellow and gold banner doesn’t get out much, but it’s most useful as a cover for your car mirror during the World Cup.
item.dc:creator: By JOCHEN BITTNER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Anticorruption Activist Sentenced to More Than 6 Years in Prison
item.description: A court has sentenced three activists, including Liu Ping, to up to six and a half years in prison, in a move some said underscored doubts about the sincerity of President Xi Jinping’s campaign against graft.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
